name: Gabapentin (Neurontin)
summary: An anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain agent often used off-label for anxiety and mood disorders.
description: Gabapentin is a structural analogue of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) that binds to the alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels in the CNS. It is approved for the treatment of partial seizures and postherpetic neuralgia, but is also widely prescribed off-label for anxiety disorders, bipolar disorder, insomnia, and alcohol withdrawal. It is not a controlled substance in most jurisdictions, but has some misuse potential.

sections.text: Binds to the alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release.

adult.partial_seizures: Start 300 mg on day 1, titrate to 900–1800 mg/day in 3 divided doses; max 3600 mg/day
adult.postherpetic_neuralgia: Start 300 mg once daily, increase to 300 mg 3 times daily over 3 days, adjust as needed

sections.pediatric: Varies by age and weight; typically 10–15 mg/kg/day divided TID, titrated as needed
sections.renal_impairment: Adjust dose according to creatinine clearance

sections.text: Onset within 1 week for pain relief; seizure control may require longer titration.

other: May cause CNS depression; caution with other sedatives
Monitor for signs of misuse or diversion

sections.pregnancy: Use if benefits outweigh risks; limited data available
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant for sedation
sections.pediatrics: Approved for seizures in children ≥3 years old
sections.geriatrics: May be more sensitive to CNS effects; start lower

sections.text: Taper gradually over at least 1 week to avoid withdrawal symptoms or seizure risk.

items: Often used off-label for anxiety and sleep
Not significantly metabolized; excreted unchanged by kidneys
Abuse potential exists in some populations
